repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Export Finance
            Intermediation Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Export Finance
            Intermediation Loan Project for Turkey were as follows:
            outcomes were highly satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was highly
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also highly
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: onerous
            environmental, procurement, and other project requirements
            tend to lead to funds being allocated to larger businesses
            rather than reaching those that need them most. The fixed
            costs incurred by these requirements make it relatively more
            attractive for Participating Financial Intermediaries (PFIs)
            to lend the loan funds to larger customers with greater loan
            sizes. PFIs indicated that project requirements made it
            uneconomical to cater to the smallest borrowers. For leasing
            companies, loan sizes under the project were roughly twice
            what they were for the leasing companies' entire
            portfolio indicating that bigger firms are targeted in the
            project. Reevaluating safeguard requirements in the context
            of credit lines and carefully designing information
            requirements to minimize compliance costs while serving the
            safeguard objectives will help ensure successful
            implementation and better achievement of the development
            objectives. During the project, loan funds for two banks in
            the project became uncompetitive and prompt reallocation to
            other PFIs ensured that the overall project was not delayed
            as a result.

docna.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Export Finance
            Intermediation Loan Project

5087400.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Trade and integration

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Export Finance
            Intermediation Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the context of the Country
            assistance Strategy (CAS), the Second Export Finance
            Intermediation Loan Project aims at providing medium, and
            long-term working capital, and investment finance to private
            exporters, and, at contributing to further facilitating
            export growth in Turkey, while also improving the quality,
            and safety of, and access to finance, through development of
            financial intermediation in the Turkish private financial
            sector by banks, and leasing companies. The project consists
            of a single component - financing of sub-loans and leases,
            to provide medium and long-term financing for the
            procurement of goods and works by private exporters. The
            Turkiye Sinai Kalkinma Bankasi (TSKB), a privately owned
            investment and development bank, is the Borrower and
            Implementing Agency for the project, and will act in the
            capacity of a wholesale institution, who will on-lend the
            loan funds. TSKB will take the credit risk on the banks, and
            leasing companies selected, and, the participating financial
            intermediaries in turn, will make sub-loans and leases to
            private exporting enterprises for procurement of goods and
            works, in order to expand their current export volumes, or
            in exceptional circumstances, to enable them to retain, and
            maintain their current exports levels. The on-lending banks,
            and leasing companies will take the credit risks on the
            borrowing enterprises. The proven due diligence of TSKB
            shows it maintains a sound financial and operational
            structure, and is fit to undertake the financial liability
            of the Loan, and operational commitments to act as a project
            implementation unit. Using the following pre-screening
            criteria, selection of participating financial
            intermediaries will be based as follows: For the banks - 1)
            total assets during the last two years to exceed a minimum
            of US$500 million equivalent on average; and, 2) export
            loans-to-total loans ratios during each of the last two
            years (for which data is available) to exceed a minimum of
            10 percent on average. For the leasing companies - 1) total
            lease receivables during the last two years to exceed a
            minimum of US$50 million equivalent on average; and, 2) new
            lease volume during the last two years to exceed a minimum
            of US$30 million equivalent on average. The creditworthiness
            of sub-borrowers will be assessed, subject to the minimum
            requirement that sub-borrowers maintain a maximum debt
            equity ratio of 80:20, and minimum debt service coverage
            ratio of 1.2:l.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Export Finance
            Intermediation Loan Project : environmental  assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The environmental assessment stipulates
            that all subprojects financed under the Second Export
            Finance Intermediation Loan Project, should be subjected to
            an environmental review process. This entails an
            environmental screening, impact assessment, and mitigation
            measures where necessary. Those subprojects under category
            I, low risk with no environmental impacts, are largely
            manufacturing of wood products, stone crafting, small scale
            metal products, software development, and art and design.
            Category II subprojects, requiring a pre- environmental
            impact assessment (EIA), should be those subprojects related
            with processing intermediate products, and production and
            storage of chemicals, petroleum, petrochemicals, as well as
            food and spirit industries, in addition to slaughterhouses,
            production of animal or vegetable oils, of milk products, or
            fresh water and marine products, among others. Subprojects
            under Category III will require a full EIA, and are such
            subprojects as refineries, gasification and liquefaction
            facilities, petrochemical complex, tire producing factories,
            or plant producing agricultural herbicides, or
            pharmaceutical products, but mostly those factories where
            flammable, and explosive compounds are produced. Finally,
            Category IV entails a list of subprojects considered
            ineligible for financing under the project, such as trade in
            wildlife, or wildlife products, release of genetically
            altered organisms into the natural environment, banned
            pesticides and herbicides, radioactive products, hazardous
            waste storage, treatment and disposal, including
            manufacturing of asbestos-containing products, nuclear
            reactors, and tobacco manufacturing.
